sn47.11:4.2: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha,
sn47.11:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn47.11:4.6: How is a great man defined?”
sn47.11:4.7: “Sāriputta, someone whose mind is free is a great man, I say.
sn47.11:4.8: If their mind is not free, I say they’re not a great man.
sn47.11:5.1: And who does someone have a free mind?
sn47.11:5.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.11:5.3: As they meditate by observing an aspect of the body, their mind loses interest, and is freed from the defilements without grasping.
sn47.11:5.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.11:5.6: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.11:5.7: As they meditate by observing an aspect of principles, their mind loses interest, and is freed from the defilements without grasping.
sn47.11:5.8: That’s how someone has a free mind.
sn47.11:5.9: Someone whose mind is free is a great man, I say.
sn47.11:5.10: If their mind is not free, I say they’re not a great man.”
